questions.question: What did early telephone operators do?
answers: Maintained cell phone towers
Connected pairs of wires to allow people to talk
Installed copper wire between cities
Sorted packets as they went to the correct destination

questions.question: What is a leased line?
answers: A boundary between leased and owned telephone equipment
A connection between a keyboard and monitor
A wire that ran from one phone company office to another
An "always on" telephone connection

questions.question: How long might a message be stored in an intermediate computer for a store-and-forward network?
answers: less than a second
no more than four seconds
less than a minute
possibly as long as several hours

questions.question: What is a packet?
answers: A technique for wrapping items for shipping
A small box used for storage
A portion of a larger message that is sent across a network
The amount of data that could be stored on an early punched card

questions.question: Which of these is most like a router?
answers: A mail sorting facility
A refrigerator
A high-speed train
An undersea telecommunications cable

questions.question: What was the name given to early network routers?
answers: Interfaith Message Processors
Internet Motion Perceptrons
Instant Message Programs
Interface Message Processors

questions.question: In addition to breaking large messages into smaller segments to be sent, what else was needed to properly route each message segment?
answers: A source and destination address on each message segment
An ID and password for each message segment
A small battery to maintain the storage for each message segment
A small tracking unit like a GPS to find lost messages

questions.question: Why is it virtually free to send messages around the world using the Internet?
answers: Because governments pay for all the connections
Because advertising pays for all the connections
Because so many people share all the resources
Because it is illegal to charge for long-distance connections

questions.question: Why do engineers use a "model" to organize their approach to solving a large and complex problem?
answers: Because it allows them to build something small and test it in a wind tunnel
Because talking about a model delays the actual start of the hard work
Because they can break a problem down into a set of smaller problems that can be solved independently
Because it helps in developing marketing materials

questions.question: Which is the top layer of the network model used by TCP/IP networks?
answers: Application
Transport
Internetwork
Link

questions.question: Which of the layers concerns itself with getting a packet of data across a single physical connection?
answers: Application
Transport
Internetwork
Link

questions.question: What does CSMA/CD stand for?
answers: Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection
Collision Sense Media Access with Continuous Direction
Correlated Space Media Allocation with Constant Division
Constant State Multiple Address Channel Divison

questions.question: What is the goal of the Internetwork layer?
answers: Insure that no data is lost while enroute
Get a packet of data moved across multiple networks from its source to its destination
Make sure that only logged-in users can use the Internet
Insure than WiFi is fairly shared across multiple computers

questions.question: In addition to the data, source, and destination addresses, what else is needed to make sure that a message can be reassembled when it reaches its destination?
answers: An offset of where the packet belongs relative to the beginning of the message
A location to send the data to if the destination computer is down
A compressed and uncompressed version of the data in the packet
The GPS coordinates of the destination computer

questions.question: What is "window size"?
answers: The sum of the length and width of a packet
The maximum size of a single packet
The maximum number of packets that can make up a message
The maximum amount of data a computer can send before receiving an acknowledgement

questions.question: In a typical networked client/server application, where does the client application run?
answers: On your laptop, desktop, or mobile computer
On a wireless access point
On the closest router
In an undersea fiber optic cable

questions.question: What does URL stand for?
answers: Universal Routing Linkage
Uniform Retransmission Logic
Uniform Resource Locator
Unified Recovery List

questions.question: When using a WiFi network to talk to the Internet, where does your computer send its packets?
answers: A gateway
A satellite
A cell phone tower
The Internet Central Office

questions.question: How is the link/physical address for a network device assigned?
answers: By the cell tower
By the Internet Assignment Numbers Authority (IANA)
By the manufacturer of the link equipment
By the government

questions.question: Which of these is a link address?
answers: www.khanacademy.com
@drchuck

questions.question: How does your computer find the gateway on a WiFi network?
answers: It has a gateway address installed by the manufacturer
It broadcasts a request for the address of the gateway
It repeatedly sends a message to all possible gateway addresses until it finds one that works
The user must enter the gateway address by hand

questions.question: When your computer wants to send data across WiFi, what is the first thing it must do?
answers: Listen to see if other computers are sending data
Just start sending the data
Send a message to the gateway asking for permission to transmit
Wait until informed that it is your turn to transmit

questions.question: What does a WiFi-connected workstation do when it tries to send data and senses a collision has happened?
answers: Keep sending the message so part of the message makes it through
Wait until told by the gateway that the collision is over
Immediately restart transmitting the message at the beginning
Stop transmitting and wait a random amount of time before restarting

questions.question: When a station wants to send data across a "token"-style network, what is the first thing it must do?
answers: Listen to see if other computers are sending data
Just start sending the data
Send a message to the gateway asking for permission to transmit
Wait until informed that it is your turn to transmit

questions.question: What is the goal of the Internetworking layer?
answers: Move packets across multiple hops from a source to destination computer
Move packets across a single physical connection
Deal with web server failover
Deal with encryption of sensitive data

questions.question: How many different physical links does a typical packet cross from its source to its destination on the Internet?
Which of these is an IP address?
answers: www.khanacademy.com
@drchuck

questions.question: Why is it necessary to move from IPv4 to IPv6?
answers: Because IPv6 has smaller routing tables
Because IPv6 reduces the number of hops a packet must go across
Because we are running out of IPv4 addresses
Because IPv6 addresses are chosen by network hardware manufacturers

questions.question: What is a network number?
answers: A group of IP addresses with the same prefix
The GPS coordinates of a particular LAN
The number of hops it takes for a packet to cross the network
The overall delay packets experience crossing the network

questions.question: How many computers can have addresses within network number "218.78"?
How do routers determine the path taken by a packet across the Internet?
answers: The routes are controlled by the IRG (Internet Routing Group)
Each router looks at a packet and forwards it based on its best guess as to the correct outbound link
Each router sends all packets on every outbound link (flooding algorithm)
Each router holds on to a packet until a packet comes in from the destination computer

questions.question: What is a routing table?
answers: A list of IP addresses mapped to link addresses
A list of IP addresses mapped to GPS coordinates
A list of network numbers mapped to GPS coordinates
A list of network numbers mapped to outbound links from the router

questions.question: How does a newly connected router fill its routing tables?
answers: By consulting the IANA (Internet Assigned Numbers Authority)
By downloading the routing RFC (Request for Comments)
By contacting the Internet Engineering Task Force (IETF)
By asking neighboring routers how they route packets

questions.question: What does a router do when a physical link goes down?
answers: Throws away all of the routing table entries for that link
Consults the Internet Map (IMAP) service
Does a Domain Name (DNS) looking for the IP address
Sends all the packets for that link back to the source computer

questions.question: Why is it good to have at least a "two-connected" network?
answers: Because routing tables are much smaller
Because it removes the need for network numbers
Because it supports more IPv4 addresses
Because it continues to function even when a single link goes down

questions.question: Do all packets from a message take the same route across the Internet?
answers: Yes
No

questions.question: How do routers discover new routes and improve their routing tables?
answers: Each day at midnight they download a new Internet map from IMAP
They periodically ask neighboring routers for their network tables
They randomly discard packets to trigger error-correction code within the Internet
They are given transmission speed data by destination computers

questions.question: What is the purpose of the "Time to Live" field in a packet?
answers: To make sure that packets do not end up in an "infinite loop"
To track how many minutes it takes for a packet to get through the network
To maintain a mapping between network numbers and GPS coordinates
To tell the router the correct output link for a particular packet

questions.question: How does the "traceroute" command work?
answers: It sends a series of packets with low TTL values so it can get a picture of where the packets get dropped
It loads a network route from the Internet Map (IMAP)
It contacts a Domain Name Server to get the route for a particular network number
It asks routers to append route information to a packet as it is routed from source to destination

questions.question: About how long does it take for a packet to cross the Pacific Ocean via an undersea fiber optic cable?
answers: 0.0025 Seconds
0.025 Seconds
0.250 Seconds
2.5 Seconds

questions.question: On a WiFi network, how does a computer get an Internetworking (IP) address?
answers: Using the DHCP protocol
Using the DNS protocol
Using the HTTP protocol
Using the IMAP protocol

questions.question: What is Network Address Translation (NAT)?
answers: It looks up the IP address associated with text names like "www.dr-chuck.com"
It allows IPv6 traffic to go across IPv4 networks
It looks up the best outbound link for a particular router and network number
It reuses special network numbers like "192.168" across multiple network gateways at multiple locations

questions.question: How are IP addresses and network numbers managed globally?
answers: There are five top-level registries that manage network numbers in five geographic areas
IP addresses are assigned worldwide randomly in a lottery
IP addresses are assigned by network equipment manufacturers
IP addresses are based on GPS coordinates

questions.question: How much larger are IPv6 addresses than IPv4 addresses?
answers: They are the same size
IPv6 addresses are 50% larger than IPv4 addresses
IPv6 addresses are twice as large as IPv4 addresses
IPv6 addresses are 10 times larger than IPv4 addresses

questions.question: What does it mean when your computer receives an IP address that starts with "169.."?
answers: Your connection to the Internet supports the Multicast protocol
The gateway is mapping your local address to a global address using NAT
There was no gateway available to forward your packets to the Internet
The gateway for this network is a low-speed gateway with a small window size

questions.question: If you were starting an Internet Service Provider in Poland, which Regional Internet Registry (RIR) would assign you a block of IP addresses.
answers: ARIN
LACNIC
RIPE NCC
APNIC
AFRNIC
United Nations

questions.question: What does the Domain Name System accomplish?
answers: It allows network-connected computers to use a textual name for a computer and look up its IP address
It keeps track of the GPS coordinates of all servers
It allows Regional Internet Registries (RIRs) to manage IP addresses on the various continents
It assigns different IP addresses to portable computers as they move from one WiFi to another

questions.question: What organization assigns top-level domains like ".com", ".org", and ".club"?
answers: IANA - Internet Assigned Numbers Authority
IETF - Internet Engineering Task Force
ICANN - International Corporation for Assigned Network Names and Numbers
IMAP - Internet Mapping Authorization Protocol

questions.question: Which of these is a domain address?
answers: www.khanacademy.org
@drchuck

questions.question: Which of these is *not* something a domain owner can do with their domain?
answers: Create subdomains
Sell subdomains
Create new top-level domains
Assign an IP address to the domain or subdomain

questions.question: What is the primary problem the Transport (TCP) layer is supposed to solve?
answers: Move packets across multiple hops from a source to destination computer
Move packets across a single physical connection
Deal with lost and out-of-order packets
Deal with encryption of sensitive data

questions.question: What is in the TCP header?
answers: Physical address
IP Address and Time to Live
Port number and offset
Which document is being requested

questions.question: Why is "window size" important for the proper functioning of the network?
answers: Because packets that are too large will clog fiber optic connections
It prevents a fast computer from sending too much data on a slow connection
It limits the number of hops a packet can take before it is dropped
It determines what part of an IP address is the network number

questions.question: What happens when a sending computer receives an acknowledgement from the receiving computer?
answers: The sending computer resends the data to make sure it was transmitted accurately
The sending computer sends more data up to the window size
The sending computer sends an "acknowledgment for the acknowledgment"
The sending computer sends the acknowledgement to the Internet Map (IMAP)

questions.question: Which of these detects and takes action when packets are lost?
answers: Sending computer
Network gateway
Core Internet routers
Receiving computer

questions.question: Which of these retains data packets so they can be retransmitted if a packets lost?
answers: Sending computer
Network gateway
Core Internet routers
Receiving computer

questions.question: Which of these is most similar to a TCP port?
answers: Train station
Undersea network cable
Apartment number
Sculpture garden

questions.question: Which half of the client/server application must start first?
answers: Client
Server

questions.question: What is the port number for the Domain Name System?
What is the port number for the IMAP mail retrieval protocol?
Which layer is right below the Application layer?
answers: Transport
Internetworking
Link Layer
Obtuse layer

questions.question: What kind of document is used to describe widely used Application layer protocols?
answers: DHCP
RFC
APPDOC
ISO 9000

questions.question: Which of these is an idea that was invented in the Application layer?
answers: www.khanacademy.com
http://www.dr-chuck.com/

questions.question: Which of the following is *not* something that the Application layer worries about?
answers: Whether the client or server starts talking first
The format of the commands and responses exchanged across a socket
How the window size changes as data is sent across a socket
How data is represented as it is sent across the network to assure interoperability.

questions.question: Which of these is an Application layer protocol?
answers: HTTP
TCP
DHCP
Ethernet

questions.question: What port would typically be used to talk to a web server?
What is the command that a web browser sends to a web server to retrieve an web document?
answers: RETR
DOCUMENT
GET

questions.question: What is the purpose of the "Content-type:" header when you retrieve a document over the web protocol?
answers: Tells the browser how to display the retrieved document
Tells the browser where to go if the document cannot be found
Tells the browser whether or not the retrieved document is empty
Tells the browser where the headers end and the content starts

questions.question: What common UNIX command can be used to send simple commands to a web server?
answers: ftp
ping
traceroute
telnet

questions.question: What does an HTTP status code of "404" mean?
answers: Document has moved
Successful document retrieval
Protocol error
Document not found

questions.question: What characters are used to mark up HTML documents?
answers: Less-than and greater-than signs < >
Exclamation points !
Square brackets [ ]
Curly brackets { }

questions.question: What is a common application protocol for retrieving mail?
answers: RFC
HTML
ICANN
IMAP

questions.question: What application protocol does RFC15 describe?
answers: telnet
ping
traceroute
www

questions.question: What happens to a server application that is sending a large file when the TCP layer has sent enough data to fill the window size and has not yet received an acknowledgement?
answers: The application switches its transmission to a new socket
The application crashes and must be restarted
The application is paused until the remote computer acknowledges that it has received some of the data
The closest gateway router starts to discard packets that would exceed the window size

questions.question: What is a "socket" on the Internet?
answers: A way for devices to get wireless power
A way for devices to get an IP address
An entry in a routing table
A two-way data connection between a pair of client and server applications

questions.question: What must an application know to make a socket connection in software?
answers: The address of the server and the port number on the server
The route between the source and destination computers
Which part of the IP address is the network number
The initial size of the TCP window during transmission

questions.question: How do we indicate that we want a secure connection when using a web browser?
answers: Use https:// in the URL
Use a secure web browser
Open an incognito window
Manually encode the address of the server using SHA1

questions.question: Why is a shared-secret approach not suitable for use on the Internet?
answers: Because people would lose or misplace the secret
It is difficult to distribute the secrets
Encryption and decryption with shared secrets are too easily broken
Encryption and decryption with shared secrets take too much compute power

questions.question: What is the underlying mathematical concept that makes public/private key encryption secure?
answers: Continuous functions
Taylor series
Karnaugh Maps
Prime numbers

questions.question: Which of the keys can be sent across the Internet in plain text without compromising security?
answers: Encryption key
Decryption Key
Shared Secret
Univerally Safe Key (USK)

questions.question: Where does the Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) fit in the four-layer Internet architecture?
answers: Below the Link layer
Between the Link and Internetworking layers
Between the Internetworking and Transport layers
Between the Transport and Application layers

questions.question: If you were properly using https in a browser over WiFi in a cafe, which of the following is the greatest risk to your losing credit card information when making an online purchase?
answers: Someone captured the packets that were sent across the WiFi
Someone captured the packets in the gateway router
Someone captured the packets as they passed through a core Intenet router
You have a virus on your computer that is capturing keystrokes

questions.question: With the Secure Sockets Layer, where are packets encrypted and decrypted?
answers: They are encrypted and decrypted as they pass through the router
Each physical link has its own separate encryption
They are encrypted in your computer and decrypted in the server
They are encrypted in the WiFi gateway and decrypted in the last router before the destination computer

questions.question: What changes to the IP layer were needed to make secure socket layer (SSL) work?
answers: No changes were needed
We had to add support for Secure IP (IPSEC)
We needed to support longer packets in IP
The Time-To-Live (TTL) value needed to be encrypted

questions.question: If a rogue element was able to monitor all packets going through an undersea cable and you were using public/private key encryption properly, which of the following would be the most difficult for them to obtain?
answers: What servers you were communicating with
How often you used the servers
How much data you retrieved from the servers
Which documents you retrieved from the servers

questions.question: What is the purpose of a Certificate Authority in public/private key encryption?
answers: To make sure people do not forge badges for learning activities
To make sure packets get routed to the correct destination computer
To assure us that a public key comes from the organization it claims to be from
To choose when a particular country must switch from IPv4 to IPv6

questions.question: The ARPANET network was in operation starting in the 1960s. Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) was not invented util the 1980s. How did the ARPANET insure the security of the data on its network?
answers: By using public/private keys and encrypting all transmissions
By using encryption at the Link layer
By making sure no one could access the physical links
By only using secure WiFi routers

answers: Ptsjduao rt dii
Wentudhs di dju
Tfdvsjuz jt gvo
Asdfghjk qw zxc

questions.question: What Caesar Cipher shift was used to encrypt "V yvxr frphevgl"?
What is the primary value of the OSI network model?
answers: OSI networks are used in the southern hemisphere
The OSI approach can be use to analyze many different network models
OSI networks make better use of limited bandwidth
OSI networks are more secure

questions.question: How many layers does the OSI model have?
answers: Four
Six
Seven
Nine

questions.question: Which of the OSI layers deals with the shape of connectors for network connections?
answers: Physical
Data Link
Network
Transport

questions.question: Which of the layers is most similar between the OSI and TCP network models?
answers: TCP Link Layer and OSI Data Link Layer
TCP Internetwork Layer and OSI Network Layer
TCP Transport Layer and OSI Transport Layer
TCP Application Layer and OSI Session Layer

questions.question: What layer does the TCP/IP Secure Sockets Layer map to in the OSI network model?
answers: Secure Data Link Layer (SDLL)
Secure Network Layer (SNL)
Secure Transport Layer (STL)
Session and Presentation Layers

questions.question: Why does the TCP model combine the OSI Data Link and Physical layers into a single Link layer?
answers: Because the TCP model does not worry about the Physical layer
Because the TCP model designers were ignored at the 1981 OSI meeting in Utrect, Netherlands
Because quite often the design of Data Link and Physical layers are tightly connected for a particular technology
To make the TCP model easier to understand by end users
